title: Welcome and introduction
segmentation: OK, let's start good morning colleagues.
We are very pleased to welcome you to this session on perspective for open education resources and technical and vocational education and training.
This is a session that we have been working on since few months together with other colleagues who will be speaking today.
My name is branch acronym, the Chief of the Section for Youth Literacy and Skills Development at UNESCO Headquarters in Paris.
And for this session I have been working with my colleague Mac Seller who is sitting here who is our lead expert in ICT in Tibet in UNESCO Univer King born.
In the organization of the session, we.
We would like to first form start by setting the scene for this session.
Then we have the pleasure to hear from Professor Overture and Professor Ben Johnson to present to study that we have been conducting on Oers in Tibet.
Then we have four representative of universe.

Network would be presenting what they're doing in this area in their specific institutions and we will have a time to have a roundtable discussion on in particular on what are the implications for in the field of Tibet and also what are the possible initiatives that we have to consider.
Another point that would be important for us is and that's helped me to set up a bit.
The background of this session and the study that we have commissioned, we have noted, since the Declaration, the purse declaration that Tibet has been neglected in the debate on Ojars.

Even if you have been in the different session yesterday, you have noted that the reference to technical and vocational education and training to skills development is very weak and even absent in the debate, the emphasis is more on tertiary education and when the speakers refer to the targets, they do refer to the targets.
The four related to two tertiary education, so it was very important for us first of all, to map about the landscape and understand what is happening, if any.

In Tibet in the field of Oers and 2nd two player, this advocacy role to say this is a field that requires attention and that there is a prospect and there is a perspective in developing or yards 40 vet to achieve the SDGS goals and the targets related to vocational education and training.
But also to achieve other goals that are very important in relation to access equity and lifelong learning.

So this is the the objective and I hope that the round table discussion will help us advancing our debate in this area and without delay I will give the floor to professors Robert Tour and Ben Johnson to present a bit the finding of the study that we have conducted.
The last few months and is really finding that we wanted to share with you today.
